Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, § 28, custody orders may be modified if there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order.

_Custody of Zia_, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.proposition: The modification must further the best interests of the children.
_Custody of Zia_, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C are made based on the best interests of the child and evaluates the change in custody under that standard. The court affirms the judge’s award of custody to the father specifically because the judge’s findings supported that this modification was in the child’s best interests. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that a custody modification must further the best interests of the child.
_Custody of Zia_, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. … In the instant matter…we cannot confidently say that the judge abused her discretion or otherwise erred as matter of law in concluding that it was in the child’s best interests to award legal and physical custody to the father.”

_Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: This warrants a modification of the existing custody order.
_Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for awarding and allocating custody in an initial determination (and in the context of dissolving a domestic partnership), not modification of an existing custody order. It does not articulate or apply the legal standard for when changed circumstances warrant modification of a prior custody judgment. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that "[some circumstance] warrants a modification of the existing custody order."
_Hunter v. Rose_, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ … ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ … The judge has discretion when awarding custody of a child to which we give ‘substantial deference.’ … There was no abuse of discretion in determining that primary physical custody of Jill should be with the plaintiff.”

_Rolde v. Rolde_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: This warrants a modification of the existing custody order.
_Rolde v. Rolde_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The case is a direct appeal from an original divorce judgment that set custody, visitation, and property division; it does not involve a post‑judgment motion to modify an existing custody order based on changed circumstances. The court affirms the trial judge’s original award of sole custody to the mother and reduced visitation, applying the best‑interests standard, rather than holding that the circumstances ‘warrant a modification’ of any prior custody order. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition that certain circumstances warrant modification of an existing custody order.
_Rolde v. Rolde_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt:
“On June 23, 1978, a temporary custody order was entered to that effect. … Following an eight-day trial the judge awarded sole custody of the children to the wife, limited Edward’s visitation rights…
…
On this record we cannot say that the judge was clearly wrong in awarding sole custody to the wife. … From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation…”

_See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas_, 395 M.proposition: It is well-established under Massachusetts law that the overriding consideration in modifying a custody order is the best interests of the children.
_See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas_, 395 M.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets the Massachusetts removal statute’s phrase “upon cause shown” to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and then states that the “central question” is how those best interests are to be determined. It further reiterates that “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern,” making clear that in custody-related modification (here, removal and custody allocation) the controlling consideration is the children’s best interests. This directly supports the proposition about Massachusetts law on modifying custody orders.
_See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas_, 395 M.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

_Edwards v. Edwards_, 377 Mass. 919, 921.proposition: It is well-established under Massachusetts law that the overriding consideration in modifying a custody order is the best interests of the children.

_See Blixt v. Blixt_, 437 Mass. 649, 655.proposition: The children’s safety, stability, and welfare are of paramount importance.
_See Blixt v. Blixt_, 437 Mass. 649, 655.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes the State’s interest in protecting children from harm and repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the child’s health, safety, welfare, and best interests, even when balancing that against parental autonomy. The court upholds the grandparent visitation statute only as narrowly tailored to the compelling state interest in protecting a child’s welfare amidst family disruption, indicating that the child’s safety, stability, and welfare are paramount in this context.
_See Blixt v. Blixt_, 437 Mass. 649, 655.relevant_excerpt: “It cannot be disputed that the State has a compelling interest to protect children from actual or potential harm. … As we shall explain more fully below, the statute can be interpreted to require a showing of harm to the child if visitation is not allowed. So interpreted, the statute furthers a compelling and legitimate State interest in mitigating potential harm to children in nonintact families… We conclude… that the statute satisfies strict scrutiny because our construction narrowly tailors it to further the compelling State interest in protecting the welfare of a child who has experienced a disruption in the family unit from harm.”

_Guardianship of Estelle_, 70 Mass. App..proposition: Where a parent allows children to be exposed to individuals who create an unsafe or inappropriate environment, the court has broad discretion to impose conditions on custody and parenting time.
_Guardianship of Estelle_, 70 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss parental exposure of children to unsafe or inappropriate individuals, nor does it address the scope of a court’s discretion to impose conditions on custody or parenting time in that context. Instead, the case is about whether, absent a finding of parental unfitness, the court may impose a co-guardianship and limit a fit parent’s custodial rights, concluding that it may not. Thus, it does not provide authority for broad discretionary conditioning of custody based on unsafe third-party exposure.
_Guardianship of Estelle_, 70 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “His solution, however, cannot stand as a matter of law because the father is correct that, absent a finding of unfitness on his part, the judge is without authority to require that he share parenting decisions with others.… As we have stated, that solution is not available if the father is found to be fit.… Should it be determined that the father is fit, he would be entitled to custody…”

_See Custody of Vaughn_, 422 Mass. 590,.proposition: The emotional trauma of witnessing violent behavior and the risk of physical injury constitute a material change in circumstances.
_See Custody of Vaughn_, 422 Mass. 590,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that witnessing domestic violence causes a “distinctly grievous kind of harm” to a child and stresses that courts must make explicit findings about the effect of such violence on the child when determining custody. However, the case is about the need to consider and make findings on domestic violence in custody decisions, not about whether that harm and risk, occurring after an earlier judgment, constitute a “material change in circumstances” for modification purposes. Thus it supports the substantive idea that emotional trauma from witnessing violence and associated risks are legally significant in custody analysis, but not specifically the ‘material change’ standard.
_See Custody of Vaughn_, 422 Mass. 590,.relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm…. It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children…. There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence, especially during important developmental stages.”

_See Ashman v. Ashman_, 1 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: _See Ashman v. Ashman_, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 414, 419 (1973).
_See Ashman v. Ashman_, 1 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Plaintiff’s requested modification—either restricting the involvement of this violent individual or requiring supervised visits—is in accordance with the Court’s authority to tailor custody orders so as to protect the children’s welfare.
_See Ashman v. Ashman_, 1 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion text provided is a criminal theft/larceny case involving store merchandise and the sufficiency of evidence for conviction. It does not concern family law, custody, visitation, or the court’s authority to structure or modify custody/visitation orders to protect children’s welfare. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the proposition about tailoring custody orders to restrict or supervise contact with a violent individual.
_See Ashman v. Ashman_, 1 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: In reviewing a claim of insufficient evidence, our function is not to weigh or resolve the question of the credibility of witnesses but rather to look to the evidence and the reasonable inferences therefrom which support the judgment of the trial court. If from that viewpoint there is evidence of probative value from which the trier of fact could find that the defendants were guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction will be affirmed.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The presence of this individual in the Defendant’s home fundamentally impacts the children’s well-being, warranting immediate intervention and adjustment of the parenting time arrangement under G.L. c. 208, § 28.
